cpp-post-retirement-benefit.important-notice: (FR) Important: OAS program and the CPP payments are not intended to cover all your needs in retirement. These public pensions provide a base upon which seniors can add income from other sources, such as employer-sponsored pension plans, registered retirement savings plans, tax-free savings accounts and other private savings, to meet their financial needs in retirement.
cpp-post-retirement-benefit.paragraph-1: (FR) If you choose to continue to work while collecting your retirement pension, you can also benefit from the CPP Post-Retirement Benefit. Each year that you work and contribute while collecting your retirement pension, up to age 70, will generate a new benefit that starts the following year and is added to your CPP income, even if you're already receiving the maximum pension. Like the retirement pension, post-retirement benefits are payable for life and indexed to the cost of living once per year. When you reach age 65, you can choose to stop making post-retirement contributions. This won't affect any post-retirement benefits you are already receiving, but will stop you from earning new ones.
cpp-post-retirement-benefit.paragraph-2: (FR) To learn more, visit the <Link>CPP Pension page.</Link>

cpp-retirement-pension.paragraph-1: (FR) The CPP retirement pension is a monthly payment that partially replaces your work earnings in retirement. The amount of your CPP retirement pension is based on your contributions to the Plan.
cpp-retirement-pension.paragraph-2: (FR) To qualify for the retirement pension, you must have contributions to the Plan for at least one year. Usually, these contributions will be from work you did, however, they may also be the result of a division of pension credits if you were divorced or ended a common-law relationship.
cpp-retirement-pension.paragraph-3: (FR) The standard age for the CPP retirement pension is 65; however, the Plan provides you with flexibility based on your needs and circumstances. You can begin your pension as early as age 60 by accepting a permanent reduction, or, you can permanently increase your monthly amount by delaying the pension up to age 70. To learn more about early and deferred pensions, visit the website [link on this website] There is no need to stop working in order to begin your pension.
cpp-retirement-pension.paragraph-4: (FR) The CPP pension amount you'll receive depends on how much and for how long you have contributed to the Plan, and at what age you decide to take your pension. The amount for CPP is increased for inflation once a year every January.

paragraph-5.content: (FR) For the most recent amounts paid to pensioners, visit this CPP payment amounts page.

cpp-retirement-pension.paragraph-6: (FR) To learn more, visit the <Link>CPP Retirement Pension page.</Link>

overview.paragraph-1: (FR) The Canada Pension Plan (CPP) is a social insurance program that provides partial earnings protection for those who have worked in Canada. The CPP offers benefits when you retire, if you become disabled, and to your estate and family when you die.
overview.paragraph-2: (FR) When you work for a Canadian employer, you and your employer contribute to the CPP. If you are self-employed, you make both the employer and employee contributions.

pillar-2.paragraph-2: (FR) Financed through employer/employee contributions and investment returns.

pillar-3.paragraph-1: (FR) Workplace pension plans and private savings
pillar-3.paragraph-2: (FR) Includes Registered Retirement Savings Plans, Tax-Free Saving Accounts and other private savings.
pillar-3.paragraph-3: (FR) Financed through employer/employee contributions and private savings

paragraph-2.content: (FR) The amount you will get from the OAS pension depends on how long you have lived in Canada after the age of 18. You will be eligible for the maximum amount if you lived in Canada for 40 years or more after the age of 18. You can qualify for the OAS pension, if you have lived or worked in another country that has a social security agreement with Canada.

old-age-security-program.overview: (FR) The Old Age Security (OAS) program provides benefits including the OAS pension and the Guaranteed Income Supplement (GIS) to seniors. You don't have to contribute to receive benefits from the OAS program. You can receive OAS benefits even if you're working or have never worked in Canada.

ongoing-earnings-from-your-job.overview: (FR) Many seniors are deciding to continue working while receiving their retirement benefits. This can mean that they are reducing their work hours from full-time to part-time before retiring completely, starting a new career or a business. If this sounds like something you're interested in, we've created a page that explains how it could impact your retirement benefits and provides some helpful tips to get you started!

personal-retirement-savings.overview: (FR) Saving money for retirement is crucial to maintain the lifestyle you want when you retire. If you don't have a pension plan from your employer, you might need to rely even more on your personal savings. There are different ways to save for retirement, but the two most common are Registered Retirement Savings Plans (RRSPs) and Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA). The government provides assistance through these savings accounts by reducing the amount of tax you pay.

rrsp.header: (FR) What is a Registered Retirement Savings Plans (RRSPs)

illustration.alt: (FR) Contributions and investment growth in your RRSP are sheltered from taxes (shown under an umbrella), however you will pay taxes on withdrawals (shown outside the umbrella

rrsp.important-notice: (FR) Important: Taking money from a RRSP will count as additional income and may change your eligibility for Guaranteed Income Supplement (GIS) in the next payment cycle that runs from July to June.
rrsp.overview: (FR) A Registered Retirement Savings Plan is a savings account that helps people save money for when they're ready to retire. When you put money into an RRSP, you don't have to pay taxes on it right away. Instead, you pay taxes on the money when you take it out of the account later, usually when you're retired and your income is lower. This way, you can save more money and pay less taxes in the long run.

tfsa.header: (FR) What is a Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA)

illustration.alt: (FR) Contributions to your TFSA are taxed (shown outside an umbrella), however investment growth and withdrawals are sheltered from tax (shown under an umbrella)

tfsa.important-notice: (FR) Important: Taking money from TFSA does not count as additional income and will not change the amount of your GIS in the next payment cycle that runs from July to June.
tfsa.overview: (FR) A Tax-Free Savings Account is another savings account that helps people save money. You have to pay tax when you put money into a TFSA but you don't have to pay taxes on the money when you take it out of the account.

list.group-tfsa: (FR) a group Tax-Free Savings Account (group TFSA)
